metadata.case_name: Appellants (Glory Restaurant & Bliss Hotel) v. State of Jammu and Kashmir

facts.text: Glory Restaurant situated in Moti Bazaar, Jammu, proprietor carried on retail sale of country and foreign liquor for last 7 years under annual licence renewed from year to year.
On December 11, 1965, Deputy Excise and Taxation Commissioner, Jammu, issued notice to appellant in CA 65 ordering shifting of premises due to complaints from inhabitants of locality.
Licence for 1965-66 expired on March 31, 1966; appellant applied for fresh licence for 1966-67 and deposited prescribed fee, but Taxing and Excise Officer refused renewal.
Bliss Hotel and Bar situated in Parade Ground, Jammu; appellant obtained first licence in 1964, spent Rs. 70,000 on furnishing but could not do business during 1964-65 due to unavoidable reasons.
Appellant in CA 66 applied for renewal for 1965-66; on December 11, 1965, received letter from Deputy Excise and Taxation Commissioner to shift premises due to complaints from inhabitants.
Licence of appellant in CA 66, along with others, collected by 3rd respondent at instance of 2nd respondent; not given licence in same locality.

Appellants filed writ petitions Nos. 2 and 4 of 1966 in Jammu and Kashmir High Court against State, Excise and Taxation Commissioner, and Deputy Excise and Taxation Commissioner seeking quashing of refusal to renew licences.
High Court Division Bench (Chief Justice and Justice Syed Murtaza Fazl Ali) dismissed writ petitions on September 16, 1966 by concurrent but separate judgments.
Respondents pleaded localities were most congested and frequented parts of city; complaints received against carrying on business there; issuing licence discretionary under Excise Act, 1958.

legal_issues.text: Whether dealing in liquor is a trade or business protected under Article 19(1)(g) of the Constitution.
Whether s.20 of the Excise Act, 1958 confers absolute discretion void under Art.19.
Whether licences were renewable as a matter of course and refusal only on grounds in s.22(a)-(d).
Whether appellants entitled to notice and opportunity before refusal to renew.
Whether order refusing renewal was arbitrary, violative of natural justice, or unreasonable restriction.

petitioner_arguments.text: If s.20 construed as conferring absolute discretion on Commissioner, it is void under Art.19.
Licence renewable as matter of course; cannot refuse renewal except on grounds in s.22(a)-(d).
Entitled to notice and opportunity to explain why licence should be renewed.
Order arbitrary; heavy expenditure incurred; no opportunity to show locality suitable and complaints false; High Court suggested inquiry for some licensees.

respondent_arguments.text: Localities most congested and frequented; complaints against business there; refused renewal bona fide in discretion under Excise Act.

court_reasoning.text: Constitutional validity of s.20 not raised in High Court; not permitted here; different views in High Court on fundamental right to liquor business.
Citizen has fundamental right under Art.19(1)(g) to carry on trade or business including liquor; State can impose reasonable restrictions in public interest.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Dealing in liquor is business; morality affects restrictions, not right itself.

court_reasoning.text: Reviewed precedents: no prior decision held liquor trade not under Art.19(1)(g); all upheld restrictions as reasonable.
Assume s.20 valid; renewal not matter of course; practice does not override statute; heavy expenditure irrelevant.
High Court finding of bona fide enquiry upheld; locality unsuitable per counter-affidavit; not arbitrary.
No notice required for non-renewal; mala fides not raised below.

holdings.text: Dealing in liquor is business under Art.19(1)(g); citizen has fundamental right subject to reasonable restrictions.
Refusal to renew licences not arbitrary or unreasonable; bona fide exercise of discretion.

precedents_cited.case_name: Narain Swadeshi Weaving Mills v. Commissioner of Excess Profits Tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Definition of business as real, substantial, systematic activity.

precedents_cited.case_name: B. Ibrahim v. Regional Transport Authority, Tanjore
precedents_cited.relevance: No absolute right to business location; subject to public convenience restrictions.

precedents_cited.case_name: Cooverjee B. Bharucha v. Excise Commissioner and Chief Commissioner, Ajmer
precedents_cited.relevance: Excise regulation reasonable restriction on liquor trade right under Art.19(6).
No inherent right to sell liquor; regulable by police power.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Assam v. A.N. Kidwai
precedents_cited.relevance: No absolute statutory right to sell liquor; controlled for health, morals, revenue.

precedents_cited.case_name: Nagendra Nath v. Commissioner of Hills Division and Appeals, Assam
precedents_cited.relevance: No inherent right to liquor shop settlement; scope of Arts.226/227.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bombay v. R.M.D. Chamarbaugwala

precedents_cited.relevance: Restrictions vary with business nature; no policy needed if not arbitrary.

statutes_cited.name: Excise Act, 1958 (Jammu and Kashmir)
statutes_cited.relevance: S.20 discretionary issuance of licences; s.22 grounds for cancellation; renewal not controlled by s.22.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Fundamental right to trade/business including liquor, subject to reasonable restrictions in public interest.

outcome.summary: Appeals dismissed upholding High Court dismissal of writ petitions; refusal to renew liquor licences in complained localities held bona fide and not arbitrary.

key_quotes.text: "dealing in liquor is business and a citizen has a right to do business in that commodity but the State can make a law imposing reasonable restrictions on the said right, in public interests."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on Art.19(1)(g) applying to liquor trade.

key_quotes.text: "A combined reading of cls. (1) and (6) of Art. 19 makes it clear that a citizen has a fundamental right to carry on any trade or business, and the State can make a law imposing reasonable restrictions on the said right in the interests of the general public."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies scope of fundamental right and restrictions.

key_quotes.text: "Standards of morality can afford a guidance to impose restrictions, but cannot limit the scope of the right."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes morality from definition of business.
